items.title: The Nobel Prize for physics is awarded for discoveries in quantum mechanical tunneling
items.standfirst: The Nobel committee said that the laureates' work provides opportunities to develop "the next generation of quantum technology, including quantum cryptography, quantum computers, and quantum sensors."
items.content: The Nobel committee said that the laureates' work provides opportunities to develop "the next generation of quantum technology, including quantum cryptography, quantum computers, and quantum sensors."(Image credit: Christine Olsson)

items.title: Nobel Prize in Physics goes to three scientists for research in quantum mechanical tunneling
items.standfirst: John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret and John M. Martinis won the 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday for research into quantum mechanical tunneling. The researchers will be formally awarded the prize at a ceremony on December 10, the anniversary of prize founder Alfred Nobel‚Äôs death.
items.content: John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret and John M. Martinis won the 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics on Tuesday for research into quantum mechanical tunneling. The researchers will be formally awarded the prize at a ceremony on December 10, the anniversary of prize founder Alfred Nobel‚Äôs death.

items.title: Nobel Prize for Physics awarded to trio for quantum mechanics discoveries
items.standfirst: Prize awarded for "discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunnelling, energy quantisation in an electric circuit".
items.content: Prize awarded for "discovery of macroscopic quantum mechanical tunnelling, energy quantisation in an electric circuit".

items.title: France's Macron gives outgoing PM 48 hours to resolve political turmoil
items.standfirst: Outgoing French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu is starting two days of last-ditch talks on Tuesday with members of various parties, a day after his shock resignation, in an effort to find a way out of the country's political crisis. Lecornu tendered his and his government's resignation on Monday morning, after his government, announced on Sunday evening, was rejected by both allies and opponents. His government was the shortest-lived administration in modern French history. FRANCE 24's Antonia Kerrigan has more details from Paris.
items.content: Outgoing French Prime Minister Sebastien Lecornu is starting two days of last-ditch talks on Tuesday with members of various parties, a day after his shock resignation, in an effort to find a way out of the country's political crisis. Lecornu tendered his and his government's resignation on Monday morning, after his government, announced on Sunday evening, was rejected by both allies and opponents. His government was the shortest-lived administration in modern French history. FRANCE 24's Antonia Kerrigan has more details from Paris.

items.title: France live: Pressure piles on Macron as former PM Philippe calls for early presidential poll
items.standfirst: France's outgoing Prime Minister S√©bastien Lecornu is meeting with political parties Tuesday in a last-ditch effort to rally support for a cabinet lineup to pull his country out of political deadlock. Earlier this morning, former French Prime Minister Edouard Philippe said he was in favour of an early presidential election. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

clusters.title: Israel and Hamas resume Gaza ceasefire talks in Egypt
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel and Hamas Resume Gaza Ceasefire Talks

items.title: Israel and Hamas resume Gaza ceasefire talks in Egypt
items.standfirst: As the war in Gaza reaches its two-year mark, Israel and Hamas continue negotiations in Egypt. Talks are centered on a proposed ceasefire deal, which includes a partial Israeli withdrawal from Gaza and a hostage-prisoner exchange. US envoy Steve Witkoff and Donald Trump‚Äôs son-in-law Jared Kushner are expected to join the discussions.
items.content: As the war in Gaza reaches its two-year mark, Israel and Hamas continue negotiations in Egypt. Talks are centered on a proposed ceasefire deal, which includes a partial Israeli withdrawal from Gaza and a hostage-prisoner exchange. US envoy Steve Witkoff and Donald Trump‚Äôs son-in-law Jared Kushner are expected to join the discussions.

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks as hopes rise of ending Gaza war
items.standfirst: Hamas‚Äôs acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas‚Äôs acceptance of key conditions of deal galvanises momentum but large gaps remain between campsIsrael and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt on a US ceasefire proposal amid cautious optimism that the nearly two-year war in Gaza may be nearing its end, despite deep divisions between the two sides.Negotiations will focus on the release of hostages held by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners in Israeli jails, as well as the partial withdrawal of Israeli troops from Gaza. The three issues constitute the first phase of a 20-point plan presented by the US president, Donald Trump, last week that aims to end the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel and Hamas begin indirect talks in Egypt, raising hopes of ceasefire and prisoner swap
items.standfirst: Israeli, Hamas and American delegations were due in Egypt to discuss a 20-point peace plan tabled by President Donald Trump to halt the conflict.
items.content: Israeli, Hamas and American delegations were due in Egypt to discuss a 20-point peace plan tabled by President Donald Trump to halt the conflict.

ai_summary: Israel and Hamas have begun indirect talks in Egypt.

Negotiations may lead to a partial Israeli withdrawal from Gaza.

clusters.title: Israelis pay respects to victims of October 7 attacks, two years on
clusters.neutral_headline: Israelis Mark Two Years Since October 7 Attacks

items.title: Israelis pay respects to victims of October 7 attacks, two years on
items.standfirst: üáÆüá± Israel marks the second anniversary of the October 7, 2023 attack, as Hamas and Israeli negotiators hold indirect talks to end the two-year war in Gaza under a US-proposed peace plan. ü™ñ Two years ago to the day, at the close of the Jewish festival of Sukkot, Hamas-led militants launched a massive assault on Israel, making it the deadliest day in the country's history and sparking a huge retaliatory offensive. üáµüá∏ Two years on, with much of Gaza flattened, tens of thousands of Palestinians killed, a UN-declared famine unfolding and Israeli hostage families still longing for their loved ones' return, global pressure to end the war has escalated massively.

items.title: Day of mourning in Israel to commemorate the October 7 attacks
items.standfirst: Today marks two years since the devastating October 7 attacks in Israel. The country observes a day of mourning to honor the victims and remember the impact of that tragic event. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has more details.
items.content: Today marks two years since the devastating October 7 attacks in Israel. The country observes a day of mourning to honor the victims and remember the impact of that tragic event. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has more details.

items.title: First Thing: Israelis gather to mark two years since 7 October Hamas attack
items.standfirst: A rally in Tel Aviv will call for release of remaining hostages in Gaza. Plus, global renewable energy generation surpasses coal for first timeGood morning.Israelis will gather across the country on Tuesday to mark two years since Hamas‚Äôs 7 October attack, which killed about 1,200 people and took 251 hostages.What is the situation on the ground in Gaza? Despite Donald Trump‚Äôs demands that Israel stop bombing the territory, strikes on the strip have continued. Gaza‚Äôs health ministry said Israel killed at least 19 people in the past 24 hours.What is Illinois arguing? The Illinois attorney general, Kwame Raoul, maintains that sending in guard troops against a state‚Äôs will violates its sovereignty and self-governance and will lead to unrest and harm for residents. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel begins commemorations marking two years since October 7 attacks
items.standfirst: On the second anniversary of the October 7 attack, sirens sounded across Tel Aviv as people gathered in Hostage Square to honor the victims of the deadliest terror attack in Israel‚Äôs history. At the Nova music festival site, survivors paid tribute to the 370 young people killed, while a growing sense of hope surrounds the possibility of a new hostage deal, though official state ceremonies are set for October 16 after the Simchat Torah holiday.
items.content: On the second anniversary of the October 7 attack, sirens sounded across Tel Aviv as people gathered in Hostage Square to honor the victims of the deadliest terror attack in Israel‚Äôs history. At the Nova music festival site, survivors paid tribute to the 370 young people killed, while a growing sense of hope surrounds the possibility of a new hostage deal, though official state ceremonies are set for October 16 after the Simchat Torah holiday.

items.title: Israel: Former Hamas hostages struggle to keep hope on October 7
items.standfirst: On the second anniversary of the October 7 attack, Israel mourns the 1,200 people killed and 251 taken hostage by Hamas. While most hostages have been released, 20 remain in captivity and 28 bodies are still held in Gaza. Freed hostage Tal Shoham, who endured 505 days in captivity, says he no longer believes peace is possible.
items.content: On the second anniversary of the October 7 attack, Israel mourns the 1,200 people killed and 251 taken hostage by Hamas. While most hostages have been released, 20 remain in captivity and 28 bodies are still held in Gaza. Freed hostage Tal Shoham, who endured 505 days in captivity, says he no longer believes peace is possible.

items.title: Israelis mark two years since October 7
items.standfirst: Israel marks the second anniversary of the October 7, 2023 attack on Tuesday ‚Äî a day of national mourning ‚Äî as Hamas and Israeli negotiators engage in indirect talks under a US-backed peace plan to end the two-year war in Gaza. The assault, launched by Hamas-led militants at the end of the Jewish festival of Sukkot, remains the deadliest day in Israel‚Äôs history. Noga Tarnopolsky is on site and speaks with relatives of the victims for FRANCE 24.
items.content: Israel marks the second anniversary of the October 7, 2023 attack on Tuesday ‚Äî a day of national mourning ‚Äî as Hamas and Israeli negotiators engage in indirect talks under a US-backed peace plan to end the two-year war in Gaza. The assault, launched by Hamas-led militants at the end of the Jewish festival of Sukkot, remains the deadliest day in Israel‚Äôs history. Noga Tarnopolsky is on site and speaks with relatives of the victims for FRANCE 24.

items.title: Former Israeli hostage recalls cruelty of Hamas captivity, sees little hope for long-term peace
items.standfirst: Former Israeli hostage Tal Shoham walked through the ruins of Kibbutz Be'eri two years after he was kidnapped from his home by Hamas gunmen during the October 7 massacre. Memories of the brutal assault and his 505 days of captivity in Gaza still haunt him.
items.content: Former Israeli hostage Tal Shoham walked through the ruins of Kibbutz Be'eri two years after he was kidnapped from his home by Hamas gunmen during the October 7 massacre. Memories of the brutal assault and his 505 days of captivity in Gaza still haunt him.

items.title: War in Gaza live: Israel 'was supposed to cease fire' under Trump plan, says Qatar
items.standfirst: Israel should have already ceased firing in Gaza under US President Donald Trump's peace plan for the Palestinian enclave, mediator Qatar said Tuesday as talks with Hamas entered a second day. The UN's chief earlier demanded the immediate and unconditional release of all hostages held in Gaza as Israel marked two years since the deadly Hamas attack on October 7, 2023. Follow our liveblog for the latest developments.

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Bari Weiss starts as CBS News' top editor
clusters.neutral_headline: Bari Weiss Starts as CBS News' Top Editor

items.title: Bari Weiss starts as CBS News' top editor
items.standfirst: Paramount‚Äôs announcement on Monday that it would acquire The Free Press and install founder Bari Weiss atop CBS News as editor-in-chief prompted questions within the storied news organization about the future of its journalism, and what the conservative opinion editor has planned. For now, Weiss‚Ä¶
items.content: Paramount‚Äôs announcement on Monday that it would acquire The Free Press and install founder Bari Weiss atop CBS News as editor-in-chief prompted questions within the storied news organization about the future of its journalism, and what the conservative opinion editor has planned. For now, Weiss‚Ä¶

items.title: CBS News names Bari Weiss as editor-in-chief
items.standfirst: Paramount Skydance also acquired The Free Press, which Weiss co-founded in 2021.
items.content: Bari Weiss, co-founder and CEO of The Free Press, has been appointed CBS News‚Äô editor-in-chief, Paramount announced on Monday. The Free Press will now operate under the company as well. It‚Äôs a major move from the company, which merged with Skydance Corp. in August under CEO David Ellison. Under Ellison, the company has made several strategic acquisitions and is reportedly exploring acquiring Warner Bros. Discovery. ‚ÄúThis move is part of Paramount‚Äôs bigger vision to modernize content and the way it connects ‚Äì directly and passionately ‚Äì to audiences around the world,‚Äù Ellison said in a statement. ‚ÄúWe believe the majority of the country longs for news that is balanced and fact-based, and we want CBS to be their home.‚Äù Though she will remain CEO and editor-in-chief of The Free Press, Weiss will report directly to Ellison. The Free Press will maintain its own independent brand and operations, the company said. Weiss and her wife, Nellie Bowles, launched The Free Press in 2021 with Weiss‚Äô sister Suzy. She was previously an opinion writer for The New York Times. Partnering with Paramount, Weiss said, allows The Free Press to expand its audience of 1.5 million. ‚ÄúThe values that we‚Äôve hammered out here over the years‚Äîjournalism based in curiosity and honesty, a culture of healthy disagreement, our shared belief in America‚Äôs promise‚Äînow have the opportunity to go very, very big,‚Äù Weiss wrote in a blog post on The Free Press. Earlier this year, CBS and Paramount settled a $16 million lawsuit with President Donald Trump over a ‚Äú60 Minutes‚Äù interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris. Paramount then hired an ombudsman to analyze bias in CBS reporting. Weiss said she believes in Ellison and ‚Äúthe entire leadership team who took over Paramount this summer.‚Äù She added that they plan to make CBS ‚Äúthe most trusted news organization of the 21st Century.‚Äù

ai_summary: Bari Weiss is starting as CBS News' top editor.
Paramount acquired The Free Press and installed Weiss.
The acquisition prompted questions about the future of journalism.
Weiss is a conservative opinion editor.
Paramount Skydance also acquired The Free Press.
